awd_titl_txt: Promoting STEM Student Success through Individualized Coaching and Interdisciplinary Community
awd_abstract_narration:
The College of DuPage (COD) STEM Student Success program will provide targeted STEM student support through the use of STEM learning communities, undergraduate research and individualized academic assistance to improve persistence among undergraduate students.  COD will award scholarships to approximately 56 students to complete a two-year program for graduation or transfer in either Chemistry, Physics, or Engineering - programs chosen for their academic rigor, extensive use of math, and existing research partnerships with four-year institutions and national laboratories.  A STEM Student Success Coach will provide individual, cohort, program-specific, and interdisciplinary guidance as a cost-effective way of addressing attrition in STEM disciplines at the community college level.  

Program objectives are to (1) Increase the number of financially needy and academically talented students who graduate or transfer in a STEM program; and to (2) Improve the retention and completion rates of STEM students through individualized and group support systems.  Enhanced educational opportunities exist through the leveraging of college resources, including partnerships with four-year institutions and national laboratories for research internships, collaboration with industry advisory boards to share STEM career paths, discussions featuring STEM professionals, and more.  Both formative and summative evaluations will allow the project team to assess all components of the program on an ongoing basis.  Quantitative/qualitative data will inform program decisions, resulting in a replicable model, disseminated through a variety of professional outlets.  The result will be a model of student support services that may be replicated at other two and four year institutions.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of our S-STEM project were to (1) increase and understand the success of low-income, academically talented Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) students with demonstrated financial need at the College of DuPage and (2) in cooperation with area partner universities, supply the workforce with two-year and four-year STEM degree students. The College of DuPage is a large two-year college in the suburbs outside Chicago. For the six-year period of this project, we provided full scholarships covering tuition and books for 85 students, and internship placements with stipends to almost 20 students.

In addition to financial assistance, the project provided the S-STEM students the services of a dedicated Student Success Coach. This coach worked to develop an in-depth relationship with the students from the start of their time joining the program. Specifically, she provided them

  • One-on-one meetings: both electronic and in-person
  • Student support services: proactive individualized academic guidance and career support through case management and coaching
  • Academic monitoring:  reviewing mid-term grade sheets or electronic records to monitor progress; mandatory meetings with the coach before dropping classes
  • Resource guides: on career exploration, resume creation, external scholarships and internship searches created and distributed to students
  • Workshops: on resumes, mindfulness, setting priorities, test anxiety, internship searching and goal-setting; plus arranged meetings with Career Services, 4-year college visits and panel discussions with successful COD alumni.

Access to the Student Success Coach had a clear, positive effect on the academic success of the STEM Scholars. The success rate was defined as the percentage of students passing a course with a C or better. This success rate for S-STEM students was compared with students having similar academic backgrounds and taking similar courses who were also receiving a similar amount of financial aid but from another source. The key difference between the two groups was the assistance of the Student Success Coach.  Figure 1 shows a statistically significant higher success rate of students in our project when averaged over the entire six-year period. It also shows an improvement in five of the six individual academic years. Figure 2 compares this success rate for the two groups for courses traditionally taken by STEM students (e.g. calculus, physics, engineering dynamics). In six of the seven courses evaluated, the students with access to the success coach performed better.

This past academic year is the one year where STEM Scholars did not outperform their peers. During this final year of the grant, the roster was tapering off and therefore there were just 13 STEM Scholars in the fall and 8 in the spring. The majority of the coursework that was not successfully completed came from 4 students. One of those students had a serious family medical situation, and 3 of the students experienced significant mental health concerns. With the small size of the group, the statistical impact of those students was large. 

When considered from the point of view of improving the success rate of our S-STEM students, overall the project was clearly a success.  In addition, although our sample size of 85 students was relatively small, the project may also point to a larger research question as to whether giving all students access to the aggressive support provided by a Student Success Coach may be worth the significant costs involved.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/24/2022
Modified by: Thomas Carter
